parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Various modifications to trawl gear have been studied for their effectiveness in reducing unwanted fish catch.
[Statement 2]: Modifying trawl gear, such as changing trawl wires, the number of nets, codend, or footrope configuration, has been found to reduce unwanted catches of non-target or discarded fish species and sizes.
[Statement 3]: Trawl gear modifications have been found to improve the size-selectivity for unwanted fish.
[Statement 4]: Using a topless trawl can reduce unwanted catches of Atlantic cod and other commercial fish species.
[Statement 5]: Bottom trawls with parts raised off the seabed have been demonstrated to reduce the catch of unwanted sharks, other elasmobranchs, and fish.
[Statement 6]: Some studies have reported mixed effects or no reduction in unwanted catch resulting from certain trawl gear modifications.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__In trawl fisheries, what are the most effective gear modifications for reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies examined the effects of establishing handling and release protocols in non-recreational fisheries on marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: One study in the Atlantic Ocean reported that tracked whale sharks released from purse seines using an enhanced protocol survived for at least 21 days.
[Statement 3]: The post-release movements of tracked whale sharks released from purse seines using an enhanced protocol appeared normal.
[Statement 4]: One study in the Pacific Ocean found that reef fish returned more quickly to a reef or the seabed after release when using protocols with minimal handling and air exposure, compared to higher stress handling and longer air exposure.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of implementing vessel decommissioning schemes on marine fish populations.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of using human observers onboard fishing vessels to monitor catches and discards on marine fish populations.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of introducing fishing permit, licence or charter schemes on marine fish populations.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for management interventions successfully reducing fishing effort?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five studies examined the effects of setting a minimum landing size for commercially fished species.
[Statement 2]: One global review found that one of five swordfish fisheries showed an increase in recruitment after setting minimum landing sizes and catch limits.
[Statement 3]: A global review found that recruitment in four of five swordfish fisheries was either highly variable or could not be assessed.
[Statement 4]: A study in the Ionian Sea found that despite minimum sizes, most commercially landed fish were immature.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of setting a maximum landing size for commercially fished species.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of specifying a capture size range for commercially fished species.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions are available to protect the reproductive success of commercially fished species?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the conservation benefits of prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves in the Mediterranean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prohibiting spearfishing in the Mediterranean can increase fish abundance and size.
[Statement 2]: Prohibiting spearfishing in the Mediterranean can particularly increase the abundance and size of species like European seabass and gilthead seabream.
[Statement 3]: Prohibiting spearfishing in the Mediterranean can lead to higher commercial and recreational catches for targeted species in surrounding areas.
[Statement 4]: Prohibiting all fishing in Mediterranean marine protected areas has been shown to result in a different fish community composition.
[Statement 5]: Prohibiting all fishing in Mediterranean marine protected areas has been shown to result in higher species richness and abundance.
[Statement 6]: Prohibiting all fishing in Mediterranean marine protected areas has been shown to result in larger fish.
[Statement 7]: Prohibiting all fishing in Mediterranean marine protected areas has been linked to an increase in fish eggs for commercially targeted species.
[Statement 8]: Prohibiting all fishing in Mediterranean marine protected areas has been linked to higher commercial fish catch rates near the reserve.
[Statement 9]: A study on prohibiting all commercial fishing in the Mediterranean found higher abundances of some targeted and non-targeted fish species after five years.

[Statement 1]: Prohibiting all mobile and static fishing gears that target bottom-dwelling species led to a higher abundance of larger and older cod.
[Statement 2]: Fish densities in areas closed to all mobile and static fishing gears for at least 11 years varied between species, depth, and temperature.
[Statement 3]: In areas closed to all mobile and static fishing gears, no change in fish densities was observed after 2–7 years.
[Statement 4]: Cod growth was better in areas closed to all mobile and static fishing gears for 5–15 years.
[Statement 5]: In areas closed to all mobile and static fishing gears, fish size varied.
[Statement 6]: When mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor were prohibited, the number of fish species and diversity varied between areas with different levels of bottom trawling.
[Statement 7]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor had no effect on species richness after a decade of protection.
[Statement 8]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor resulted in higher total fish biomass or biomass of certain species like red mullet and seahorses after 1–15 years.
[Statement 9]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor showed no impact on the abundance of bottom-dwelling fish species.
[Statement 10]: After 14 years of prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor, the recruitment of young red mullet increased.
[Statement 11]: No increase was found for the recruitment of young haddock after seven years of prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor.
[Statement 12]: After 14 years of prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor, larger red mullet were noted.
[Statement 13]: The effect on fish size from prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor was variable.
[Statement 14]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor sometimes had no effect at all on fish size.
[Statement 15]: Prohibiting mobile fishing gears dragged across the seafloor revealed no reduction in unwanted catch after seven years.
[Statement 16]: Prohibiting seine nets led to higher overall fish catch rates.
[Statement 17]: In an area where all but one gear type was prohibited, a higher fish density was observed compared to other areas.
[Statement 18]: A combination of prohibiting non-selective gear types and long-term closures reduced the unwanted catch of cod.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the effects on marine fish populations of prohibiting different types of bottom fishing gear?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are some alternatives to setting catch quotas for controlling fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the USA found that using modified crab pots with mesh chimneys reduced the mortality of diamondback terrapins.
[Statement 2]: A study in the Indian Ocean (South Africa) found that prohibiting offshore line fishing in a marine protected area resulted in higher abundances and larger sizes of four over-exploited fish species.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of prohibiting the catching and/or landing of specific fish species on marine fish populations.

[Statement 1]: A review of six studies found the majority (76-92%) of discarded or protected small-spotted catshark, thorny skate, pearl perch, and Atlantic wolffish survived for at least 1 hour to 5 days after capture.
[Statement 2]: A review found that less than half of smooth skate survived after capture.
[Statement 3]: Fish survival was found to be reduced by hooking or capture depth injuries.
[Statement 4]: Fish survival was found to be reduced by longer tow durations.
[Statement 5]: One study showed that nearly all yelloweye rockfish survived for four days after capture.
[Statement 6]: The survival of canary rockfish decreased with increasing capture depth.
[Statement 7]: All spinetail devilrays that were brailed aboard from purse seine nets survived.
[Statement 8]: Spinetail devilrays brought aboard entangled in a purse seine net did not survive.
[Statement 9]: A global review of longline fishing indicated that using nylon hook attachment lines instead of wire resulted in higher survival for two out of three shark and ray species.
[Statement 10]: A global review of longline fishing indicated that using nylon hook attachment lines instead of wire resulted in lower survival for one shark and ray species.
[Statement 11]: A study in the Atlantic Ocean found that the survival of unwanted sharks caught on tuna longlines was reduced with nylon hook lines compared to wire hook lines.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What does the evidence say about how different fishing practices affect the survival of fish after capture and release?
_gemini-2-5-pro__How do the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The effects of prohibiting fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins.
[Statement 2]: In marine protected areas across the Indian, Atlantic, Mediterranean, Pacific, Tasman, Coral, Philippine, Caribbean, Gulf of Mexico, and Sulu Seas, 30 of 54 studies found higher fish abundances.
[Statement 3]: The effect of prohibiting fishing can differ based on factors like species, the species' position in the food chain, and habitat.
[Statement 4]: Other studies found varied effects or similar abundances between fished and protected areas.
[Statement 5]: After prohibiting all commercial fishing, two of four studies in the Mediterranean Sea, Indian Ocean, South Atlantic Ocean, and Gulf of Mexico reported higher abundances for some species.
[Statement 6]: A study in the South China Sea noted an increase in overall fish density in the region surrounding new marine reserves.
[Statement 7]: A study in a Tasman Sea estuary observed a lower abundance for most fish species two years after the area was closed to fishing.
[Statement 8]: In the South Pacific Ocean, prohibiting commercial lobster fishing did not lead to an increase in lobster abundance over 12 years.

[Statement 1]: Setting catch limits or quotas for non-commercially targeted fish reduced unwanted catch in two of three cases in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
[Statement 2]: A study in the Pacific Ocean found that catch limits for non-target commercial species reduced the amount of unwanted halibut.
[Statement 3]: Using a different bait type reduced the unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod and other unwanted or non-target fish in six of eight studies.
[Statement 4]: Two studies found no reduction in unwanted catches of pelagic stingray and overall unwanted fish with different bait types.
[Statement 5]: Two systematic global reviews found that using different bait types did not affect the number of unwanted sharks and rays caught.
[Statement 6]: One study found that using a different bait species increased the size-selectivity of commercially targeted Greenland halibut.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most effective non-gear-modification strategies for reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the North Sea indicated that after vessels with higher engine power were excluded from an area for half of each year, there was a higher abundance of commercially targeted fish.
[Statement 2]: The same study showed there was no difference in the overall abundance of non-commercially targeted fish over five years.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What management actions are available to specifically protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Three studies were found that examined the effect of involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management of marine fish populations.
[Statement 2]: One study in the Indian Ocean found that involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management increased overall fish abundance.
[Statement 3]: A study in the Pacific Ocean found no decrease in overall fishing effort.
[Statement 4]: A study in the Pacific Ocean found no increase in total fish catch rates.
[Statement 5]: A study in the South China Sea reported a decrease in illegal fishing using destructive fishing gears after co-management was established.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of engaging fishers in scientific data collection on marine fish populations.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of involving stakeholders in the allocation of harvest rights on marine fish populations.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the state of evidence for the effectiveness of involving fishers and other stakeholders in marine conservation management?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most effective operational tactics for fishers to reduce unwanted catch without modifying the main structure of their nets or lines?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A review in the North Pacific and North Atlantic Oceans found that using technology to provide near real-time catch information to fishers resulted in reductions in unwanted catch or discards.
[Statement 2]: The reductions in unwanted catch or discards occurred in two of three cases.

[Statement 1]: The use of different hook types in longline or recreational fisheries is an alternative management strategy.
[Statement 2]: Studies have shown that modifying hook type, including size and style, can reduce the incidence of injuries and capture mortality for some unwanted sharks, rays, and billfish species when compared to conventional hooks.
[Statement 3]: The use of different hook types has been found to reduce the unwanted catch of non-commercially targeted and small non-target fish species.
[Statement 4]: Increasing hook size can improve the size-selectivity for certain species by increasing the average catch length.
[Statement 5]: Some studies found that changing hook type did not reduce the capture mortality of other non-target species.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found that changing hook type did not reduce the unwanted catch of young or non-target fish.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine fish populations of purchasing fishing permits to limit vessel or fisher numbers.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects on marine fish populations of specifying a size range for commercially fished species.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Besides closing areas to fishing, what alternative management strategies can reduce overall fishing mortality?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Unspecified fishing restrictions in marine protected areas have been studied for their effects on marine fish and invertebrate populations.
[Statement 2]: For marine fish, the introduction of unspecified fishing restrictions within a marine protected area has been shown to result in higher fish species richness inside the reserves compared to areas without fishing restrictions.
[Statement 3]: The introduction of unspecified fishing restrictions within a marine protected area has been shown to result in higher fish abundance inside the reserves compared to areas without fishing restrictions.
[Statement 4]: Fish inside marine protected areas with unspecified fishing restrictions were found to be of a larger average size.
[Statement 5]: For invertebrate populations, marine protected areas with some fishing restrictions were found to have more lobsters, scallops, sea cucumbers, hydrozoans, and sponges when compared to fished areas.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions are available within a marine protected area to manage fishing activity without imposing a complete ban on all fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Modifications to trawl gear, such as changes to the length of the extension piece, the codend strengthening bag, the method of weaving, the number of codend layers, and overall design, improved the size-selectivity for unwanted fish species or sizes.
[Statement 2]: Changes to trawl wires, number of nets, codend number, footrope configuration, front trawl body panels, spreading mechanism, knot orientation, or using a new overall trawl design resulted in reduced unwanted catches of non-target and/or discarded fish species or sizes.
[Statement 3]: Turning the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° resulted in better size selection of cod, red mullet, common pandora, and round-bodied fish species compared to standard orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends.
[Statement 4]: Turning the orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends by 90° did not result in better size selection of plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species compared to standard orientation of diamond mesh in trawl codends.
[Statement 5]: Using turned mesh instead of standard diamond mesh trawl codends did not improve the size selectivity of cod, plaice and flounder.
[Statement 6]: Reducing the size of the main body of a trawl net did not improve the size-selection of cod and haddock.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which modifications to trawl nets appear most effective for improving size-selectivity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the Indian Ocean indicated that prohibiting offshore line fishing and other boat-based fishing within a marine protected area resulted in a greater abundance and larger sizes of four over-exploited fish species.
[Statement 2]: Six of eight replicated studies found that using different bait types, such as variations in size, species, and manufacturing method, led to a reduction in unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod, and other non-target fish.
[Statement 3]: Two other studies found no decrease in the unwanted catches of pelagic stingray and other fish when using different bait types.
[Statement 4]: Two global systematic reviews found that altering bait types did not impact the number of unwanted sharks and rays caught.
[Statement 5]: One replicated study and one global systematic review showed that different bait species did not lessen hooking injuries in undersized snapper or sharks and rays.
[Statement 6]: Different bait species did not improve the survival rate of sharks and rays when the gear was retrieved, according to one replicated study and one global systematic review.
[Statement 7]: A replicated study in the Denmark Strait revealed that using a different bait species enhanced the size-selectivity of fishing gear for commercially targeted Greenland halibut.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented effects of different restrictions on line fishing, such as prohibitions or gear modifications, on fish populations and unwanted catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish.
[Statement 2]: Shrimp trawls fitted with a mesh size-sorting funnel, or sieve net, reduced the catches of unwanted, non-commercial, or discarded fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 3]: Using a topless trawl reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species compared to conventional trawl types.
[Statement 4]: Using a topless trawl in combination with another non-conventional trawl type reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species.
[Statement 5]: Topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock compared to standard trawl types.
[Statement 6]: Topless trawls did not reduce unwanted catches of smaller haddock compared to standard trawl types.
[Statement 7]: In some cases, topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger Atlantic cod compared to standard trawl types.
[Statement 8]: Four designs of W-trawl nets used in shrimp/prawn fisheries caught less non-commercial unwanted catch of crustaceans compared to a traditional Florida Flyer trawl net.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, what gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Modifying the configuration of gillnets, such as reducing the gillnets' height, increasing tension, twine diameter, mesh size, and altering orientation, has been found to reduce the unwanted catch of cod and other discarded commercial and non-commercial species.
[Statement 2]: One study noted that gillnet modification did not typically reduce unwanted shark catches.
[Statement 3]: For fishing traps and pots, modifications such as using a different trap type, increasing mesh size, or fitting an escape device have been shown to reduce unwanted catches of various species including brown trout, black sea bass, herring, cod, protected rockfishes, sharks, and rays.
[Statement 4]: Using square mesh escape windows or larger mesh sizes can improve the size-selectivity for species like Atlantic cod and black sea bass.
[Statement 5]: Some studies found that trap modifications had no effect on the unwanted catches of white croaker and undersized Atlantic cod.
[Statement 6]: In one case, trap modifications increased the bycatch of haddock.
[Statement 7]: Changing the type of bait, including the bait's size, species, and manufacturing method, has been found to reduce unwanted catches of undersized haddock and Atlantic cod.
[Statement 8]: Other studies found that different bait types did not reduce the unwanted catches of pelagic stingrays, other fish, sharks, or rays.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most effective modifications for static fishing gear, like gillnets and traps, to reduce unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four designs of W-trawl nets used in shrimp/prawn fisheries were found to catch less non-commercial unwanted crustaceans compared to a traditional Florida Flyer trawl net in one study in Moreton Bay, Australia.
[Statement 2]: The four designs of W-trawl nets also caught lower amounts of the commercially targeted prawn species.
[Statement 3]: In the North Sea, three studies found that shrimp trawls fitted with a size-sorting mesh funnel, or sieve net, reduced the catches of unwanted and non-commercial or discarded fish compared to standard trawls.
[Statement 4]: Two out of four studies in the North Sea, Gulf of Maine, and Baltic Sea found that using a topless trawl reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species when compared to conventional trawls.
[Statement 5]: Another study showed that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock and, in one of two cases, larger Atlantic cod.
[Statement 6]: A fourth study found that topless trawls reduced discarded catches of one of four commercial fish species.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish in commercial prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five of six studies found that rotating the orientation of diamond mesh in a trawl net by 90 degrees led to better size selection for species like cod, red mullet, common pandora, and other round-bodied fish.
[Statement 2]: Rotating the orientation of diamond mesh in a trawl net by 90 degrees did not improve size selection for plaice, annular sea bream, or flatfish species.
[Statement 3]: One study found that rotating the orientation of diamond mesh in a trawl net by 90 degrees did not improve size selectivity for cod, plaice, or flounder.
[Statement 4]: Other modifications to trawl gear have also been shown to improve size-selectivity for unwanted fish species or sizes.
[Statement 5]: Trawl gear modifications that improve size-selectivity include changes to the length of the extension piece, the codend strengthening bag, the method of weaving, the number of codend layers, and the overall design of the gear.
[Statement 6]: One study found that reducing the size of the main body of a trawl net did not improve the size-selection of cod and haddock.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What is the evidence for gear modifications improving the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the Adriatic Sea found that a marine protected area zone permitting only artisanal fishing for three years had higher overall commercial catch rates for five of seven species.
[Statement 2]: The catch rates in a marine protected area zone permitting only artisanal fishing were compared to unprotected areas that were openly fished.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented ecological outcomes of managing small-scale traditional fisheries, either through prohibition or by making them the only permitted fishing type?
